articles.headline: G.M. Documents Reveal Years of Talks on Defect
articles.snippet: Files released by House investigators include an email telling Mary T. Barra, now the chief executive, of steering problems in 2011.
articles.abstract: Files released by House investigators include an email telling Mary T. Barra, now the chief executive, of steering problems in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Mary T. Barra, the new chief executive of General Motors, told a panel of stern and dubious House members that she first became aware of a serious safety issue with the Chevrolet Cobalt in December, two months before the company announced a recall that would eventually cover 2.6 million cars.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Financial Advice for People Who Aren’t Rich
articles.snippet: The new companies began with the idea of advising young adults on their finances, then discovered that people over 50 also wanted help.
articles.abstract: The new companies began with the idea of advising young adults on their finances, then discovered that people over 50 also wanted help.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a couple of years now, a number of entrepreneurs have been racing to solve the same problem: the financial services industry’s persistent inability to provide personalized advice and appropriate investments at a reasonable price to customers who are not rich.

articles.headline: Battle for the Bigger Screen
articles.snippet: Big chains are adding large-format screens in an effort to find new ways to grow in the United States and Canada, where business has been softening for a decade.
articles.abstract: Big chains are adding large-format screens in an effort to find new ways to grow in the United States and Canada, where business has been softening for a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On the surface it’s just an old-fashioned game of Hollywood tit for tat: Cinemark, the nation’s No. 3 theater chain, has been promoting the growth of its network of extra-large movie screens, and Imax, the standard-bearer in the format for decades, has reacted with popped claws.

articles.headline: Sebelius’s Slow-Motion Resignation From the Cabinet
articles.snippet: By Thanksgiving, it was clear that Kathleen Sebelius, the departing Health and Human Services secretary, would eventually have to go.
articles.abstract: By Thanksgiving, it was clear that Kathleen Sebelius, the departing Health and Human Services secretary, would eventually have to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Everyone knew it was a disaster. After Kathleen Sebelius appeared on “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” last October, she and her staff at the Department of Health and Human Services felt she had been sandbagged by Mr. Stewart. At the White House, President Obama’s top aides were aghast at her wooden performance.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear

articles.headline: China Takes On Big Risks in Its Push for Shale Gas
articles.snippet: While China is eager to wean itself from energy imports and coal, its extraction of shale gas is likely to be more expensive and dangerous than elsewhere.
articles.abstract: While China is eager to wean itself from energy imports and coal, its extraction of shale gas is likely to be more expensive and dangerous than elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIAOSHIZHEN, China — Residents of this isolated mountain valley of terraced cornfields were just going to sleep last April when they were jolted by an enormous roar, followed by a tower of flames. A shock wave rolled across the valley, rattling windows in farmhouses and village shops, and a mysterious, pungent gas swiftly pervaded homes.

articles.headline: Franken’s Campaign Against Comcast Is No Joke
articles.snippet: After a failed attempt to block the Comcast-NBC Universal merger, Senator Al Franken again finds himself playing a trustbusting role in Washington.
articles.abstract: After a failed attempt to block the Comcast-NBC Universal merger, Senator Al Franken again finds himself playing a trustbusting role in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Senator Al Franken, the political became personal at a “Saturday Night Live” cast party, of all places.

articles.headline: Thought Secure, Pooled Pensions Teeter and Fall
articles.snippet: Pensions in multiemployer plans were once believed to be extremely reliable, but changing economic circumstances have left vulnerable the pools and the federal insurance plan meant to support them.
articles.abstract: Pensions in multiemployer plans were once believed to be extremely reliable, but changing economic circumstances have left vulnerable the pools and the federal insurance plan meant to support them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pensions of millions of Americans are being threatened because of trouble in a part of the retirement world long considered so safe that no one gave it a second thought.

articles.headline: Pay for Performance? It Depends on the Measuring Stick
articles.snippet: Many companies’ pay metrics are ineffective in motivating executives to create shareholder value.
articles.abstract: Many companies’ pay metrics are ineffective in motivating executives to create shareholder value.
articles.lead_paragraph: Year after year, as executive pay continues its inexorable climb, it’s amusing to watch corporate directors try to justify the piles of shareholder money they throw at the hired help. Check out any proxy filing for these arguments, which usually center on how closely and carefully the executives’ incentive compensation is tied to the performance of company operations.

articles.headline: Executive Pay: Invasion of the Supersalaries
articles.snippet: The compensation of corporate chief executives, up again in 2013, is drawing more scorn as an engine of income inequality.
articles.abstract: The compensation of corporate chief executives, up again in 2013, is drawing more scorn as an engine of income inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate America’s well-oiled compensation machine is running like a dream.

articles.headline: Buyers Find Tax Break on Art: Let It Hang Awhile in Oregon
articles.snippet: A lucrative, little-known tax maneuver has produced a startling pipeline of art moving across the United States as collectors cleverly — and legally — exploit the tax codes.
articles.abstract: A lucrative, little-known tax maneuver has produced a startling pipeline of art moving across the United States as collectors cleverly — and legally — exploit the tax codes.
articles.lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — The Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art, tucked into a quiet corner of a college campus here in the hills of the Pacific Northwest, is hardly the epicenter of the art world. Yet major collectors, fresh from buying a Warhol or a Basquiat or another masterpiece in New York, routinely choose this small, elegant redbrick building at the University of Oregon to first exhibit their latest trophy.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: From Boom to Rust, Lavish Projects Are Languishing in Brazil
articles.snippet: An array of projects conceived when economic growth was surging now stand abandoned, stalled or wildly over budget, fueling accusations of waste, incompetence and corruption.
articles.abstract: An array of projects conceived when economic growth was surging now stand abandoned, stalled or wildly over budget, fueling accusations of waste, incompetence and corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: PAULISTANA, Brazil — Brazil plowed billions of dollars into building a railroad across arid backlands, only for the long-delayed project to fall prey to metal scavengers. Curvaceous new public buildings designed by the famed architect Oscar Niemeyer were abandoned right after being constructed. There was even an ill-fated U.F.O. museum built with federal funds. Its skeletal remains now sit like a lost ship among the weeds.

articles.headline: North Carolina Shows Strains Within G.O.P.
articles.snippet: In North Carolina’s high-profile Republican primary for Senate, the divisions gripping the party nationally are playing out loudly and expensively.
articles.abstract: In North Carolina’s high-profile Republican primary for Senate, the divisions gripping the party nationally are playing out loudly and expensively.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — There is a Tea Party candidate who talks about the Constitution and has the backing of Senator Rand Paul. There is a Baptist pastor, endorsed by Mike Huckabee, who wears a “Jesus First” lapel pin and has led the fight against same-sex marriage. And there is a Republican state lawmaker — supported by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and $1 million from Karl Rove’s American Crossroads group — standing up for the party establishment.

articles.headline: Ukraine Forces Storm a Town, Defying Russia
articles.snippet: The Ukrainian government on Sunday for the first time sent in its security services to confront armed pro-Russian militants who took over a police station in the country’s east, Ukrainian officials said.
articles.abstract: The Ukrainian government on Sunday for the first time sent in its security services to confront armed pro-Russian militants who took over a police station in the country’s east, Ukrainian officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The Ukrainian government on Sunday for the first time sent its security services to confront armed pro-Russian militants in the country’s east, defying warnings from Russia. Commandos engaged in gunfights with men who had set up roadblocks and stormed a Ukrainian police station in Slovyansk, and at least one officer was killed, Ukrainian officials said.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: Pistorius Versus the Pit Bull: Fierce Prosecutor Shares Stage
articles.snippet: Gerrie Nel, whose cross-examinations have earned him the nickname pit bull, has turned his judicial laser on Oscar Pistorius, who is charged in the murder of his girlfriend.
articles.abstract: Gerrie Nel, whose cross-examinations have earned him the nickname pit bull, has turned his judicial laser on Oscar Pistorius, who is charged in the murder of his girlfriend.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — It was a corruption trial that had transfixed South Africa, and the prosecutor was in no mood for mercy. The defendant was the nation’s top police official, a figure of such international stature that he had once led Interpol. But when he took the stand, his testimony — his wife, he said, had accidentally shredded evidence — was rejected outright by his inquisitor.

articles.headline: Local News, Off College Presses
articles.snippet: As financial pressures force newspapers to close or make cuts, college journalism students are picking up the slack in many communities.
articles.abstract: As financial pressures force newspapers to close or make cuts, college journalism students are picking up the slack in many communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — In January, residents here learned the news that the senior place-kicker for the University of Michigan’s football team had been permanently “separated” from the college for violating its student sexual misconduct policy. In addition, the violation, what the authorities said was a sexual assault, occurred in 2009, when the kicker was a freshman, and his punishment was not determined until his athletic career had ended this past winter.

articles.headline: Obama Effect Inspiring Few to Seek Office
articles.snippet: A State Senate candidate in Massachusetts is one of President Obama’s few former aides who is running for office; far more have joined the ranks of high-paid consultants.
articles.abstract: A State Senate candidate in Massachusetts is one of President Obama’s few former aides who is running for office; far more have joined the ranks of high-paid consultants.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUDLOW, Mass. — Eric Lesser was shaking hands with diners in a Portuguese restaurant last week when he spotted the owner of Manny’s TV & Appliances. “Oh, I’ve got to get a picture,” Mr. Lesser eagerly said, draping his arm over Manny Rovithis, whose low-budget commercials have run for decades in Western Massachusetts. Mr. Lesser’s giddiness about meeting the local celebrity had not faded when he sat down for lunch.

articles.headline: Yahoo Rolls the Dice on TV
articles.snippet: Winning in the distribution of high-end content is about mining an audience, and you can’t blame technology companies for believing they have relevant skill sets.
articles.abstract: Winning in the distribution of high-end content is about mining an audience, and you can’t blame technology companies for believing they have relevant skill sets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yahoo, a company that seems like a permanent adolescent in search of an identity, is about to try a new persona: high-quality television programmer.

articles.headline: Rich Start-Ups Go Back for Another Helping
articles.snippet: As investment money continues to pour into Silicon Valley, start-ups already flush with cash are being given sizable additional rounds of venture capital.
articles.abstract: As investment money continues to pour into Silicon Valley, start-ups already flush with cash are being given sizable additional rounds of venture capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: Quora, a question-and-answer website, didn’t need to raise money. It had barely touched $60 million in venture capital that it accepted just two years ago.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Year After the Boston Marathon Bombings, Injured Brothers Endure
articles.snippet: J. P. and Paul Norden each lost a leg in the Boston Marathon bombings one year ago, but they do not want to be defined by a single moment of violence.
articles.abstract: J. P. and Paul Norden each lost a leg in the Boston Marathon bombings one year ago, but they do not want to be defined by a single moment of violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: STONEHAM, Mass. — When two bombs transformed last year’s Boston Marathon into a war zone, the Norden family absorbed a double dose of grief. J. P., 34, and his brother Paul, 32, both strapping construction workers in their prime who were there to cheer on a friend, each lost a leg in the carnage.

articles.headline: In New Officers’ Careers, Peace Is No Dividend
articles.snippet: West Point graduates, faced with the prospect of leading troops who are battle-tested when they themselves are not, are reconsidering their career paths in a military no longer fighting two wars.
articles.abstract: West Point graduates, faced with the prospect of leading troops who are battle-tested when they themselves are not, are reconsidering their career paths in a military no longer fighting two wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — Col. Jeff Lieb, the deputy commandant of the United States Military Academy and a veteran of the war in Iraq, paced before a group of cadets standing in formation and shouted at them about their lives after graduation.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: The Art of ‘Something From Nothing’
articles.snippet: By producing and investing in a series of successful start-ups like Expedia, Zillow and Glassdoor, Richard Barton has managed to accomplish something few others have done.
articles.abstract: By producing and investing in a series of successful start-ups like Expedia, Zillow and Glassdoor, Richard Barton has managed to accomplish something few others have done.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Entrepreneurs are lucky to have one big score. Richard Barton has had a string of them, by repeatedly asking the same simple question: What piece of marketplace information do people crave and don’t have?

articles.headline: Ukraine Falters in Drive to Curb Unrest in East
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal on Monday to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev, where political leaders and security forces have few reliable ways to confront Russian-backed separatists in the restive east.

articles.headline: Citi Profit Exceeds Forecasts
articles.snippet: Even as its quarterly profits brightened, Citigroup disclosed that it had found an additional case of fraud at Banamex, its Mexican unit.
articles.abstract: Even as its quarterly profits brightened, Citigroup disclosed that it had found an additional case of fraud at Banamex, its Mexican unit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors and analysts feared the worst from Citigroup, the global bank that has been besieged for months by regulatory problems and an industrywide trading slump.
